name: James
comment info: I notice that the graph has no y axis or scale. I wonder why this is? I definitely go to the movies more often in the summer. My headline: "A slow bleed, how the box office continues to lose its summer revenue."

replies.comment info:

name: Lindsey D
comment info:
1. The graph shows the top 5 summer movies by how much money they made in the U.S. each year from 2019 to 2025. Movies made between $1.6 billion and $2.6 billion, and the highest total was in 2019 with $2.6 billion. The 2025 numbers are preliminary, which means they might change.

2. Why did the top summer movies make less in 2025 than in earlier years? Are there any causes? The ones I can think of would be fewer people going to the movies and fewer big hits. 

3. Summer movies usually make a lot of money, but the amount can go up or down. Superhero or animated movies appear in the top 5, which shows they are really popular. The drop in 2025 could mean that people's movie-watching habits are changing.

4. This shows what kind of movies a lot of people in the U.S. like to watch during summer break or vacation. It makes me think about how entertainment trends can change and how movies are a big part of culture during the summer. Maybe it explains what movies people my age are talking about or excited to see.

name: Finlay
comment info:
Title: Reimagined and Remade: Franchises and Remade movies sell best. 

Notice: All of these movies are targeted toward a younger audience, maybe from ages 6-30. This might mean that companies are focusing more on the younger generation than trying to capture the attention of older generations.
In 2019, all of the shown movies are remakes and sequels. These sold the best in theaters, maybe suggesting that humans enjoy familiar franchises rather than new movies. To add to this, the movies lower in revenue are new movies and not remakes.

Wonder: Why do original movies sell better than remakes? 
Why wouldn't people like new experiences and stories, and rather prefer the same story repeated?

name: Henry
comment info:
Box Office Breakers; The fall of The Summer Blockbuster

There is a steady drop of the revenue each year. 
Most movies on this list are parts of pre-existing franchises. Which asks the question; what is next for independent movies?
The movie revenues have dwindled since the pandemic. Likely because the pandemic put theaters out of business
There is usually one animated movie on the list per year. 

If this trend continues, what does it mean for movie theaters?
Most of these movies are actionful and thrillers, is that what cinema has become? 
There is only a few R rated films on here, why?
